Line 118: Line 118:
Following the election on 7 October 2010, Ed Miliband appointed his Shadow Cabinet on 8 October 2010. Amongst others he appointed [[Alan Johnson]] as [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer]], [[Ed Balls]]
Following the election on 7 October 2010, Ed Miliband appointed his Shadow Cabinet on 8 October 2010. Amongst others he appointed [[Alan Johnson]] as [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer]], [[Ed Balls]]
became [[Shadow Home Secretary]] and [[Yvette Cooper]] was chosen as [[Shadow Foreign Secretary]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www2.labour.org.uk/labours-new-shadow-cabinet{|title=Labour's New Shadow Cabinet|publisher=[[Labour Party (UK)]]|accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref>
became [[Shadow Home Secretary]] and [[Yvette Cooper]] was chosen as [[Shadow Foreign Secretary]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www2.labour.org.uk/labours-new-shadow-cabinet{|title=Labour's New Shadow Cabinet|publisher=[[Labour Party (UK)]]|accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref>
  +   +
==Views==
  +
=== Politics ===
  +
{{Main|Ed Miliband's political views}}
  +
{{Empty section}}
  +   +
===Religion===
  +
{{Expand section}}
  +   +
In an interview with the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' in August 2010, in answer to questions about his upbringing he said:<ref name="evening standard">{{cite news |title=Ed Miliband reveals agenda for power with Labour... and a personal insight |publisher=Evening Standard |date=31 August 2010 |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/politics/article-23872359-ed-miliband-reveals-agenda-for-power-with-labour-and-a-personal-insight.do |accessdate=22 October 2010 |location=London}}</ref> <blockquote>Obviously I'm Jewish, it is part of my identity, but not in a religious sense. I don't wish I had had a more religious upbringing but I have Jewish friends who were part of the Jewish community growing up, going to Jewish youth clubs and other things. I think I felt slightly jealous. My parents' community was the Left community.</blockquote>
  +   +
And in another interview in the ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' in November 2010, Miliband conveys:<ref>[http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/40603/ed-miliband-hamas-ken-livingstone-and-jewish-values My Jewish identity was such a substantial part of my upbringing that it informs what I am]</ref> <blockquote>My Jewish identity was such a substantial part of my upbringing that it informs what I am.</blockquote>
  +   +
After previously commenting that his religious views were a private matter, in an interview with [[Radio 5 Live]] he said in reply to a question from [[Nicky Campbell]], "I don't believe in God personally, but I have great respect for those people who do."<ref name="tel2010-09-29">{{cite news |title=Ed Miliband: I don't believe in God |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=29 September 2010 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/ed-miliband/8032163/Ed-Miliband-I-dont-believe-in-God.html |accessdate=29 September 2010 |location=London}}</ref>
